Stretching/Warming up is EXTREMELY important.
Muscle tightness caused me to miss almost a week of training because it made me dizzy, increased my heart rate, vomiting, lose of appetite, trouble breathing normally etc.

Having to deal with stuff like that makes those 2-5 min of warm-up worth it.
I used to be one of those dudes who didn't care for warming up but after that experience I will never skip warm-ups or stretching ever again.

I don't really care what the studies say about stretching not helping with soreness. Every time I don't stretch after a workout, I get DOMS and my muscles are not ready to be worked again the next time I train. If some study goes against what I have found, then a) the study's scope was limited, b) the result is for the average (for half of the people it helps, for half it hurts) or c) there are outliers and I am one of them (for example I'm somewhat hyper mobile, so that could be a factor). Nevertheless, generalizations suck.

Throughout my life I have played a number of different sports and I have also done quite a bit of weight lifting and working out at gyms. The coaches that I had always stressed how important it was to stretch and warm up before we practiced or started our weight lifting. So, since I was taught that way I have always thought that stretching and warming up were very important so I didn't get hurt. It does make sense though, that if you stretch too much before certain things it can decrease your muscle strength. Now that I am no longer actively playing a sport, I typically go to the gym to work out. I have gotten into a habit of not stretching anymore before I work out because it didn't really seem to be helping, but I still warm up a little before I get started. If I am sore I tend to stretch to help with it and typically it does help loosen me up a bit. I agree with the video though that the more flexible you are the easier you could get hurt. I knew someone in high school who was extremely flexible and she was always getting hurt. I still think that warming up before you start to do any kind of exercise is very important. It warms up your muscles and get your heart pumping and helps your body get prepared for whatever you are going to do. I completely agree the warming up before exercise will help your body more than if you don't.

Yes, too much stretching can be bad for you but only if you over stretch your muscles. If you over stretch your muscles then there will be a decrease in muscle strength this occurs because once over stretched the same muscle become unresponsive for up to 30 30 mins.

warming up has to account for fitness level of every athlete/participant. The more fit you are the quicker your body adapts to exercise. The less fit you are, the body requires at least 10-15min of exercise at 70-75% of your max effort. The reality is that someone can overdo warming up and start fatiguing glycogen stores and therefore diminishing performance for the intended event/activity. Listen to your body.

Ugh stop. I'm a ballet dancer meaning extreme flexibility compared to the average human and I use to play competitive sports. Stretches that aren't intense and generally made to loosen up some tight spots are perfectly fine before sports time, it's only when more intense stretches are done, especially if you are naturally leas flexible, right before you need to play. The key is to do light stretches closer to game time and harder ones a few hours before. Same thing with ballet! I do oversplits about three hours before myclass, and once I get there all I do are gentle stretches for sore parts of my body. Being inflexible affects how injury prone you are, but super flexibility does not if it is countered with strength! Flexibility usually means more ROM less strength but if ROM is countered with support from the muscles you will be fine! Keep stretching guys <3

This video is a disservice to any young athlete or a newbie sportsman, stretching is important for every athelete, stretching improves posture, relieves holding patterns and relaxes tight muscles and ligaments. If you are regularly engaging in a demanding physical activity that implies moving forcefuly, rapid changing of directon and wide range of periactivity motion, you should stretch daily. It is common to encounter an athlete that does not stretch for whatever reason. Making this video that claims stretching can be detrimental is like making one that claims being too restrictive with your diet can cause physical nad metal anguish. We all know thats true, but when you have obesity crisis you would benefit more by showing people how to feed properly by restricting their calorie and sodium intake. The same goes for stretching, making a video that discredites stretching by stating it might be bad in certain ammount ( and you didnt state what ammount) only enforces bad training choices by newbie athletes  who arent prone to it to begin with.

I'd like to elaborate on the complex relationship of stretching with skiing/snowboarding. It's good to stretch regularly if you participate in these sports so that your body is flexible, but you shouldn't stretch right before actually doing them because you need a certain amount of tension in your muscles to maintain control. Stretching may make you too loose and tend to crash, thereby increasing injury rates.

Further evidence that, try as we might, everything eventually ends.  Like life, there is death.  To prolong our existence indefinitely just seems so unnatural and artificial.  Our natural instinct is to survive and grow, but stronger than any desire or action we take is the ultimate reality of our passing.  From dust we came, to dust we return.  The planet which gave rise to vast, proud oceans, magnificent, majestic snow-capped mountains, wild, untamable beasts, fragrant, delicate flowers, and so many wonderful creations will melt back into one big, uniform rock.  It's so poetic, and beautiful in its own way.  All stories, including the one that science gives, have a beginning, middle, and end.  I just wish that we will be able to pass that story on, all the while weaving into it the essence of the intricate, enduring human spirit, and that someone else may listen and enjoy it, tasting the pleasures we have so dearly experienced, and perhaps even taken for granted.

So.. Does flexibility good? #sciencesays

For people who are still confused after this video, here's what you should take away:

Dynamic Stretching, which is taking joints through a range of motion while moving (i.e. Skipping, jogging, leg swings, arm circles) is important pre-exercise. 

Static Stretching, which is your classic sit and reach hamstring stretch, butterflies, hurdler stretch and things of that nature, have little effect on performance and are more likely decrease muscle strength and power than to help. 

You can read up on this as there have been tons of scholarly articles written about the efficacy of stretching. 

For those who want a quick answer: static stretching is bad because prolonged stretching causes the muscle length to increase via increased sarcomere length, which in turn decreases the number of active actinomyosin cross-bridges. Actin and myosin are the two tiny little parts within the muscle which cause contraction, so when the muscle is stretched and less actin and myosin heads are able to come into contact, YOU can't create as much force aka you are slower, weaker, and less explosive. boom.

You shouldn't static stretch before exercise.  Your muscle fibers are like rubber bands. If you stretch and hold a rubber band, it loses its elasticity.  This is how your muscles react to to stretching and holding the stretch for too long, or "static stretches". However,  static stretches after workouts are beneficial.  For preworkout stretching I would recommend dynamic,  or active stretching.  Active isolated stretching is preferred for pre workout as well.

My dance teacher explained this to me.

When you warm up, you need to exercise both flexibility and strength. If you're really strong, but you aren't that flexible, you're going to pull a muscle or a tendon. If you're really flexible, but you're not strong enough, you can't do as much work and you can strain or overwork your muscles.

Balance between flexibility and strength is key!

Based on my studies of this in college and experience with my cross country teammates, warming up is most beneficial for athletes who engage in quick and/or explosive movements. Also, static stretching is not recommended prior to a workout or competition (shown in video). Dynamic stretching is best beforehand because it combines the stretch your body needs while keeping the body warm. Both my teammates and myself experienced fewer injuries when we switched from static to dynamic stretching.

I feel like this video is trying a to answer a different question than what is really being asked. The question is whether or not stretching can improve athletic performance. Were not trying to answer whether highly flexible people do better at sports than non flexible people. If your going to evaluate this like a bell curve, than of course the medium level of flexibility is going to perform the best. But that doesn't say anything about whether the act of stretching itself increases or decreases athletic performance.
